channel.title: Internet's Broke... Again, Invalid I.p adress
channel.description:
Well, Hey again guys... im having problems with my internet again and im on my sisters currently and i've turned off the modem and turned it back on and it didnt work -The provider is virgin media -It isnt the network card -it says [b]'The procedure entry point HrIsIpstatecheckingenabled could not be located in the dynamic link libary netshell.dll'[/b] when i click 'repair' also above it says [b]'your machine appears to have an invalid i.p adress'[/b]
I think this is to do with my LAN Setting's, my internet comes from a modem which goes to a router, the router goes to 4computers all the computers but mine are working.
Thank's Blaps,
Also i've emptied my cookies. and still isnt working

item.title: Internet's Broke... Again, Invalid I.p adress
item.dc:creator: @zammyking111 zammyking111
item.description:
@zammyking111 wrote:

Try this…

Go to start>run>cmd>ipconfig /all
Once you’ve done that go to
start>control panel>network and internet connections>network connections>
right click your local lan or whatever there is go to properties then go down to
internet protocol (TCP/IP)
click it then when its highlighted choose properties then hit the use the following IP address
Then put in the info then do that same with DNS
So you get all your info from the CMD and put it into the internet options

Hope this helps

Ps: if that doesnt work its the drivers fault or computers fault

Read full topic
item.source: Internet's Broke... Again, Invalid I.p adress

item.title: Internet's Broke... Again, Invalid I.p adress
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It’s almost certainly not network settings, looks like a driver problem or a fuxed windows dll.

SFC will replace the windows dll if that is the problem, yes it needs your windows cd.

Read full topic

@Original_Daniel wrote:

Just ring tech support. They will solve it quicker than anybody here. You probably just need to reconfigure your settings by connecting to your router and re-making the connection.

I don’t think its your LAN settings.

Try running “sfc /scannow” (no quotes ofc).
